IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: Human Impact Partners transforms the field of public health to center equity and builds collective power with social justice movements.
IRS990.MissionDesc: Human Impact Partners transforms the field of public health to center equity and builds collective power with social justice movements.
IRS990.Desc: Capacity building: HIP provides training, technical assistance, and leadership development to support public health organizations and practitioners to take action on health and racial equity, and power-sharing with communities. In 2022, HIP provided training and/or technical assistance to 26 state or local health departments and/or public health organizations across 17 states and Washington DC to advance health equity. Our 2022-23 cohort of Health Equity Awakened Leadership Institute brought together 18 leaders from 11 health departments across the country to do leadership development and advance racial and social justice strategies for public health. We also deepened our long-term relationships with NACCHO and ASTHO, the associations representing local and state health departments, respectively, and published numerous new resources for public health both the field broadly and health departments specifically to improve their systems, policies, and practices to advance health equity goals.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: Organizing: HIP builds a base of public health workers to use our voice, evidence, expertise, and resources to take collective action and build community power. In 2022, our Public Health Awakened initiative now consisting of over 3,000 public health professionals in all 50 states continued to support rapid response COVID organizing, hosted our first somatics workshops for public health folks with over 150 participants, and supported the ongoing movement to end the Title 42 order on migrants, among other campaigns. Our Health Instead of Punishment program launched an Abolitionist Public Health Student Network for public health students to learn more about abolition and work together on campus campaigns. Last years two student cohorts comprised 125 students from over 25 different campuses, who met to learn about abolition and organizing strategy and workshop their own campus campaigns. Advocacy: HIP amplifies the use of public health research, expertise, framing, and communications to support targeted campaigns and movements. In 2022, HIP brought the voice of public health to 75+ local, state, and federal campaigns by signing on to campaigns; speaking at press conferences and public hearings; organizing health professionals to make public statements in the context of legislative and administrative debates; helping to collect public comments about federal rule changes; and producing fact sheets and infographics to bring a health lens to policy making.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: Awareness building: HIP creates and disseminates transformative narratives and communications that shift dominant paradigms about health equity causes and solutions. In 2022, HIP created over 27 unique resources to support public health capacity building, advance social movement campaigns, and strengthen power-building; hosted 12 webinars, spoke on over 20 external panels, and presented at or attended 9 national conferences and convenings; and reached a newsletter subscriber audience of over 10,000 with monthly health equity highlights, updates, and tools. We also trained over 200 public health professionals in a new narrative training and development curriculum that we co-developed to introduce narrative power as a strategy for health equity, and convened a narrative Community of Practice that meets monthly to share learnings, workshop challenges, and identify narrative applications.

IRS990ScheduleA.FactsAndCircumstancesTestTxt: Prior Year Facts and Circumstances: Human Impact Partners 202210% Facts & Circumstances StatementThe Organization has evaluated the five-factor facts and circumstances test and believes it should continue to be treated as a public charity. The Organization receives more than 10% of its support from public sources. It is actively engaged in attracting additional public support on an ongoing basis. It has a representative governing board. It makes its programs broadly available. As the Organization is not a membership organization, the fifth factor is not applicable. Percentage of public support. The Organizations public support is 29.65%, substantially above the 10% facts and circumstances threshold. The Organization already attracts meaningful public support, intends to be publicly supported, and is actively engaged in activities that are intended to attract new and additional public or governmental support on a continuous basis. Sources of support. The Organization currently attracts support from government sources, individuals and community groups, and continues to expand its sources of support, particularly from governmental sources of support.Availability of public facilities or services. Most of the organizations program services are available to the broad general public free of charge; the remaining services are delivered to local and state government agencies to support their public services. The Organization publishes its research findings for free on its public website and invests significant resources in publicizing its research through media coverage and speaking engagements. It also develops public health resources and materials for public and community entities to use, and trains and builds the capacity of other organizations to achieve their charitable and public interest goals. Participation in the Organizations activities is open to the public and events are widely publicized in advance.Representative governing body. The Organization has a fully independent volunteer Board of Directors, none of whom are compensated for their services, nor family of founders, officers, or other Board members. Board members bring their expertise in the fields of public health, medicine, nonprofit management, and grassroots community organizing, with specific and relevant knowledge gained through their work at governmental departments of public health, schools of public health, public interest nonprofits, and other related organizations.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Internal Revenue Service and the California Franchise Tax Board have determined that the Organization is exempt from federal and state income taxes under IRC 501(c)(3) and California RTC 23701(d). The Organization has evaluated its current tax positions as of December 31, 2022 and is not aware of any significant uncertain tax positions for which a reserve would be necessary. The Organizations tax returns are generally subject to examination by federal and state taxing authorities for three and four years, respectively, after they are filed.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Grantees sign a written agreement which includes an established scope of work and timeline for specific deliverables. We continuously monitor the grant deliverables and ensure grant goals are accomplished.

OTHER PROGRAM SERVICES 4: Organizing: HIP builds a base of public health workers to use our voice, evidence, expertise, and resources to take collective action and build community power. In 2022, our Public Health Awakened initiative now consisting of over 3,000 public health professionals in all 50 states continued to support rapid response COVID organizing, hosted our first somatics workshops for public health folks with over 150 participants, and supported the ongoing movement to end the Title 42 order on migrants, among other campaigns. Our Health Instead of Punishment program launched an Abolitionist Public Health Student Network for public health students to learn more about abolition and work together on campus campaigns. Last years two student cohorts comprised 125 students from over 25 different campuses, who met to learn about abolition and organizing strategy and workshop their own campus campaigns. Advocacy: HIP amplifies the use of public health research, expertise, framing, and communications to support targeted campaigns and movements. In 2022, HIP brought the voice of public health to 75+ local, state, and federal campaigns by signing on to campaigns; speaking at press conferences and public hearings; organizing health professionals to make public statements in the context of legislative and administrative debates; helping to collect public comments about federal rule changes; and producing fact sheets and infographics to bring a health lens to policy making.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Draft 990 is emailed to full board for review in advance; 990 submission is approved by vote of the full board.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Annually at the first Board meeting of the year, Directors are asked to complete the conflict of interest form. All responses are reviewed by a Co-Director to ensure they are compliant with our conflict of interest policy.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Board or Board committee is responsible for reviewing comparability data and documenting its decisions when Co-Director compensation is to be reviewed and changed.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
